No use, distribution or reproduction is permitted which does not comply with these terms. Background The increasing prevalence of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs), such as the plasmid-mediated tigecycline-modifying enzyme tet Methods Between June 2023 and December 2024, 140 wastewater samples from 15 swine farms in Shandong, China, were screened for tet Raoultella ornithinolytica Results tet R. ornithinolytica Escherichia coli bla NDM –5 –6 R. ornithinolytica Klebsiella pneumoniae Conclusion The tet R. ornithinolytica : tet Raoultella ornithinolytica IncFII plasmid Klebsiella pneumoniae tigecycline The author(s) declare that financial support was received for the research and/or publication of this article. This work was supported by the Young Scientists Fund of the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 32302927), and the Basic Public Welfare Research Project of Wenzhou Science and Technology Bureau (Grant No. 2023Y1770). pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement yes pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes section-at-acceptance Antimicrobials, Resistance and Chemotherapy Introduction The rise in antibiotic resistance presents a significant threat to human health. By 2035, resistance to last-resort antibiotics is projected to be 2.1 times higher than that in 2005. Currently, around 7.7 million people die each year from bacterial infections, of which antibiotic-resistant bacteria cause 4.95 million deaths ( Okeke et al., 2024 Gupta et al., 2019 Chu et al., 2024 Holvoet et al., 2013 Onalenna and Rahube, 2022 mcr tet Aminov, 2021 mcr Sun et al., 2023 Wang et al., 2020 Since the discovery of novel tet He et al., 2019 Sun et al., 2019 Zhang et al., 2020 tet Cui et al., 2020 2022 Fan et al., 2024 Fang et al., 2020 tet E. coli tet K. pneumoniae Liu X. et al., 2024 Yue et al., 2024 Zhang et al., 2024 tet Fang et al., 2020 Li et al., 2020 R. ornithinolytica Klebsiella Raoultella Drancourt et al., 2001 Hajjar et al., 2020 R. ornithinolytica R. ornithinolytica Hajjar et al., 2020 Jones et al., 2024 K. pneumoniae bla KPC–2 mcr Xedzro et al., 2023 tmexCD-toprJ Zhu et al., 2023 In this study, a tet R. ornithinolytica R. ornithinolytica K. pneumoniae Materials and methods Sample collection and identification of tet From June 2023 to December 2024, we collected a total of 140 non-repetitive sewage samples during the monitoring of sewage resistance in swine farms in Shandong Province. A total of 140 sewage samples were obtained from 15 different farms distributed across five cities, with each farm contributing between 7 and 14 samples. A total of 50 μl of sewage sample was transferred to 800 μl of LB broth and cultured overnight at 37 degrees with shaking. Then, overnight cultures were inoculated onto LB agar plates containing 2 mg/L tigecycline using an inoculation loop. Detection of common tigecycline resistance genes using PCR in resistant colonies. 16S DNA and Sanger sequencing were used for strain identification. Antimicrobial susceptibility testing Antimicrobial susceptibility of strains was determined by agar dilution method according to Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines ( Humphries et al., 2018 European Committee on Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing [EUCAST], 2025 E. coli Conjugation experiments To verify the transferability of the pSD8-1-2 plasmid, filter mating experiment was performed using the E. coli K. pneumoniae E. coli K. pneumoniae Plasmid stability The stability of pSD8-1-2 was investigated by conventional plate count method. Briefly, a single colony of freshly cultured SD8-1 was inoculated into 4 ml of antibiotic-free LB broth and cultured at 37 °C with shaking. The culture was then subcultured in antibiotic-free LB broth at a ratio of 1:1000, subcultured every 12 h, twice a day, for 25 consecutive days. The culture was taken every day, serially diluted, and then inoculated onto antibiotic-free LB agar plates. Following overnight incubation, 50 colonies were randomly selected for PCR amplification of the tet tet Growth curve measurement and statistical analysis Single colonies of all strains to be tested were selected and inoculated into LB broth, and cultured overnight at 37 °C and 200 rpm with shaking. After adjusting the overnight culture to the 0.5 McFarland turbidity standard, it was diluted 1:100 in LB broth. The optical density was measured at a wavelength of 600 nm (OD 600 600 600 μ = ln ⁢ ( OD 2 ) - ln ⁢ ( OD 1 ) t 2 - t 1 The area under the curve (AUC) of the growth curve was calculated using the trapezoidal rule with the formula: AUC = ∑ i = 1 n - 1 ( OD i + OD i + 1 ) 2 ⋅ ( t i + 1 - t i ) All data are presented as mean ± standard deviation ( n t p Mouse bloodstream infection model To verify the pathogenicity of the SD8-1 strain and the effect of the pSD8-1-2 plasmid on tigecycline treatment, we constructed a bloodstream infection model in mice. All experiments were performed in accordance with the principles and procedures in the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals of the National Institutes of Health and approved by the Experimental Animal Ethics Committee of Wenzhou Medical University. Male BALB/c mice aged 7 weeks were housed and had free access to food and water. Neutropenia was induced in mice by intraperitoneal injection of cyclophosphamide twice, the first dose was 150 mg/kg and the second dose was 100 mg/kg, injected 3 days and 1 day before infection, respectively. Each mouse was injected with 1 × 10 6 Whole-genome sequencing Genomic DNA from a tet R. ornithinolytica de novo 1 2 Liu et al., 2019 R. ornithinolytica Results Identification and antimicrobial susceptibility testing of R. ornithinolytica From June 2023 to December 2024, 38 tet E. coli Enterobacter cloacae Myroides Proteus mirabilis R. ornithinolytica Supplementary Table 1 Genomic analysis of R. ornithinolytica Whole-genome sequencing of SD8-1 was performed using short- and long-read approaches. The genome comprises a 5,489,588 bp chromosome and four plasmids: 78,159, 75,774, 33,222, and 10,755 bp. Average nucleotide identity analysis confirmed its identity as R. ornithinolytica R. ornithinolytica aadA16 aac(6’)-Ib-cr bla PLA bla TEM–1B fosA floR catA2 qnrB6 ARR-3 sul1 dfrA27 tet tet bla PLA fosA tet Supplementary Table 2 fimH fyuA irp2 mchF nlpI Characterization of tet The IncFII(pCRY)-like plasmid pSD8-1-2, harboring tet Figure 1 tet Klebsiella CP077430.1 MW940621.1 CP135167.1 CP109771.1 tet TEM–1 LAP–2 tet Figure 1 Klebsiella K. pneumoniae AS1 kra4 26 CR2 tet CR2 tet Cui et al., 2020 2022 Jin et al., 2024 CR2 tet FIGURE 1 Linear sequence comparison of pSD8-1-2. Regions of homology are marked by shading. Arrows show the direction of transcription of open reading frames. The delta (Δ) symbol indicates a truncated gene. T4SS component, antimicrobial resistance, transposases, etc., are marked according to the colors in the legend to indicate their functions. This figure illustrates the syntenic comparison of tet(X)-harboring plasmids. It compares Klebsiella pneumoniae strains from various sources and years, including human, swine, and pork. Homology is shown by shaded regions, with arrows indicating the transcription direction of open reading frames (ORFs). The delta (Δ) symbol marks truncated genes. Functional regions such as T4SS components, antimicrobial resistance genes, and transposases are color-coded to highlight their distribution and conservation across different plasmids. This figure helps to understand the genetic diversity and evolution of tet(X)-carrying plasmids in various isolates. Given the dissemination of pSD8-1-2 and related plasmids in K. pneumoniae Figure 2a E. coli bla NDM E218 –5 –6 K. pneumoniae E. coli E. coli R. ornithinolytica p Figures 2b, c p p Figure 2d FIGURE 2 Analysis of bacterial growth and plasmid stability. (a) tet (b) 600 (c) (d) t p Analysis of bacterial growth and plasmid stability. Panel (a) shows the plasmid stability of pSD8-1-2 over 25 days, with a sharp decrease in plasmid retention over time. Panel (b) displays growth curves for various bacterial strains (E218, E218-p, ΔSD8-1, SD8-1, C600, C600-p) measured by OD600 over 12 hours. Panel (c) presents the growth rates (μ) of the strains during the logarithmic phase. Panel (d) shows the area under the curve (AUC) of the growth curves, with statistical significance indicated by asterisks and “ns” for non-significant comparisons Effect of pSD8-1-2 on in vivo To assess the pathogenicity of R. ornithinolytica in vivo 6 Figure 3a Figure 3b Figure 3c tet in vivo FIGURE 3 Histopathological analysis of mouse tissues in a bloodstream infection model with tigecycline treatment. (a) (b) (c) Histopathological analysis of mouse tissues in a bloodstream infection model with tigecycline treatment. Panels (a), (b), and (c) show H&E staining of lung, liver, and kidney tissues, respectively, from control, SD8-1, and ΔSD8-1 groups. The images demonstrate structural differences among the groups after tigecycline treatment. In the liver and kidney panels, regions of interest are highlighted with yellow squares, showing areas with significant changes in tissue morphology. The scale bar in each panel represents 100 μm. Global distribution and resistance gene/replicon profiles of R. ornithinolytica To investigate the prevalence and distribution of antibiotic resistance in R. ornithinolytica R. ornithinolytica Figure 4a n n n n Figure 4b n Figure 4c oqxA oqxB fosA bla PLA R. ornithinolytica oqxAB fosA bla PLA th th bla OXA bla TEM aph(6)-Id bla KPC sul1 aph(3’)-Ia Figure 4d mdfA dfrA14 qnrS1 dfrA14 R. ornithinolytica mcr tmexCD-toprJ R. ornithinolytica K. pneumoniae R. ornithinolytica Figure 4e R. ornithinolytica FIGURE 4 Global distribution and resistance profile of R. ornithinolytica (a) R. ornithinolytica (b) (c) (d) (e) Map illustrating the distribution of strains worldwide with a color gradient indicating numbers from 1 to over 100. Bar graphs detail strain sources, yearly data from 2003 to 2018, and prevalence rates by categories, using different shades of blue to indicate quantities.
